channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dilma Rousseff Targeted in Brazil by Lawmakers Facing Scandals of Their Own
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil is accused of using money from giant public banks to cover budget gaps, damaging the nation’s economic credibility. A pivotal vote in her impeachment case is expected this weekend.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: Many of the legislators calling for President Rousseff’s impeachment are facing charges that some observers say are more serious than the accusations against her.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Justin Trudeau Seeks to Legalize Assisted Suicide in Canada
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has said his support for doctor-assisted death was informed by the last days of his father, former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.
item.description: The prime minister has introduced legislation to address the legal void left after Canada’s Supreme Court overturned a ban on doctor-assisted death.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Angela Merkel Allows Turkey to Press Case Against German Comic
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann at an awards ceremony in Düsseldorf, Germany, in January. The German comedian faces a lawsuit over his lampooning of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.
item.media:credit: Rolf Vennenbernd/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Chancellor Merkel’s move to allow a court case against the comic, Jan Böhmermann, made clear that she cannot afford to antagonize President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whom he lampooned.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: After Europe and Turkey Strike a Deal, Fears Grow That Migrants Will Turn to Italy
item.media:description: A woman in Siracusa, Italy, gave money to an African migrant outside a church on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: With an agreement reached to curb the flow of refugees into Greece, there is new focus on a dangerous sea route from Libya to Italy.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: 2nd Strong Quake Hits Southern Japan; Some Reported Trapped
item.description: A powerful earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.1 struck southern Japan early Saturday, barely 24 hours after a smaller quake hit the same region and killed nine people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Taliban Revive Attack on Kunduz City, Alarming Afghans
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel searched commuters at a checkpoint in Kunduz Province on Friday.
item.description: Officials said they ended the assault on the city, but fear remained that lack of unity among the Army and the police could weaken security.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: As China’s Growth Slows, Banks Feel the Strain of Bad Debt
item.media:description: A construction site in Beijing on Friday. China’s total local-currency loans have more than tripled since the start of 2009.
item.description: Chinese lenders feel rising pain from souring loans in troubled industries — even as they face pressure to keep local companies afloat.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: At U.N., Ambassadors Hold Auditions for Next Secretary General
item.description: He or she will face daunting challenges, from stopping wars, to holding peacekeepers accountable for rape, to nudging governments to tackle climate change.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: 2 Years After Boko Haram Kidnapping, the Search Goes On for Nigerian Girls
item.media:description: Members of the Bring Back Our Girls movement gathered in Lagos on Wednesday for a rally calling for the release of Nigerian girls kidnapped by Boko Haram.
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The mass abduction, on April 14, 2014, was just one of hundreds of acts of brutality that Boko Haram has rained down on West Africa in recent years.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Artist Nurtures a Creative Oasis in Conservative Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: As low oil prices have shaken the Saudi economy, the artist Abdulnasser Gharem has started a project called “Prosperity Without Growth” that uses red and yellow oil drums
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Abdulnasser Gharem has taken artistic aim at what he sees as the kingdom’s byzantine bureaucracy, religious dogmatism and dependence on oil.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Saudi Arabia Moves to Curb Its Feared Religious Police
item.media:description: Women outside a shopping mall in Riyadh last year. “Young women are irritated to no end by the religious police,” said Bernard Haykel, a professor of Near Eastern studies at Princeton.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: The kingdom announced steps to overhaul the force, saying members could no longer detain or pursue suspects, and should be “gentle and kind,” rather than heavy-handed.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Russian Forces Remain Heavily Involved in Syria, Despite Appearances
item.media:description: A Syrian man carried a carpet along a street in Palmyra, a town that Russian forces helped Syria retake from Islamic State fighters.
item.description: Russian attack helicopters replaced jets as Russia operates a secretive war in its effort to influence the political outcome in Syria.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Kremlin Apologizes to German Newspaper for Wrongly Tying It to Goldman Sachs
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arriving to speak with journalists after his annual live call-in show in Moscow on Thursday.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin misspoke when he said Süddeutsche Zeitung, which published reports about the Panama Papers, was owned by Goldman Sachs.
item.dc:creator: OLEG MATSNEV

item.title: E.U.’s Five Biggest Economies Join Tax Crackdown After Panama Papers
item.media:description: George Osborne, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, said the agreement demonstrated that “no single country can tackle international tax evasion alone.”
item.description: Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Spain have agreed to share information on company ownership and that urged the Group of 20 Nations to do the same.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Chinese General Visits Disputed Spratly Islands in South China Sea
item.media:description: Chinese soldiers on the Spratly Islands, known in China as the Nansha Islands, in February. The sign at the right reads, “Nansha is our national land, sacred and inviolable.”
item.description: Although the details of the trip were sparse, it appeared intended to show China’s determination to ward off any challenges to its claims over the islands.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Taiwan Fears Fraud Suspects in Malaysia Risk Being Deported to China
item.media:description: Chinese and Taiwanese suspected of being involved in wire fraud, in center seats, arriving at Beijing Capital International Airport on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Yin Gang/Xinhua News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Legislators in Taiwan warned that dozens of its people could be sent from Malaysia to mainland China, echoing a similar incident involving Kenya.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: News Analysis: In South China Sea Visit, U.S. Defense Chief Flexes Military Muscle
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter attended the closing ceremony of a joint United States-Philippine military exercise in Quezon City, Philippines, on Friday.
item.description: Ashton B. Carter’s tour sent a message that Americans would work with allies to counter Beijing’s expanding presence, but China may feel a need to speed up its own military buildup.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Spanish Castle’s Restoration, Called ‘Disaster’ by Some, Wins Prize
item.media:description: The restoration of the Matrera Castle in southern Spain has drawn comparisons to a botched amateur restoration in 2012 of a nearly century-old fresco of Jesus in the county’s northeast.
item.description: The award, from Architizer, is a vindication of sorts for the architect Carlos Quevedo Rojas, who reinforced stone battlements with a wall of mortar.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Belgium’s Transportation Minister Resigns Amid Outcry
item.media:description: The transportation minister of Belgium, Jacqueline Galant, in Brussels on Thursday. She came under heavy criticism this week, with opposition lawmakers demanding that she go.
item.description: Jacqueline Galant stepped down after the publication of leaked reports warning of security deficiencies at Brussels Airport, which was bombed on March 22.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Spain’s Industry Minister Steps Down Over Panama Papers Revelations
item.media:description: José Manuel Soria, the Spanish minister of industry, energy and tourism, in Parliament on Wednesday. His name appeared in the Panama Papers.
item.description: The resignation of José Manuel Soria, who has not been charged with wrongdoing, comes at a time of turmoil in Spanish politics, after inconclusive elections in December.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: North Korea Ballistic Missile Launch a Failure, Pentagon Says
item.description: The Defense Department said that its radar systems “detected and tracked” a North Korea launch that “did not pose a threat to North America.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: First-Quarter Growth Slows a Bit in China, as Expected
item.media:description: A construction site in Beijing. Traditional industries like steel, mining and manufacturing, which relied on housing construction, are mired in a brutal downturn.
item.description: China said its economy grew 6.7 percent, the slowest quarterly rate since the financial crisis in 2009 but also exactly what economists had forecast.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Canada Extends Benefits to People of Mixed Aboriginal and European Ancestry
item.description: A ruling by the country’s Supreme Court will affect about 600,000 people who had been in a “jurisdictional tug of war” between the federal government and provinces.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Colombia Reports First Cases of Microcephaly Linked to Zika Virus
item.description: Though the two cases were the first confirmed in the country since the infection spread there, officials said they did not expect the birth defects to reach the same scale as in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and MARÍA EUGENIA DÍAZ

item.title: Health Officials Split Over Advice on Pregnancy in Zika Areas
item.media:description: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, described the internal debate over Zika and pregnancy as “a very long conversation.”
item.description: Some experts say avoiding conception is the only sure way to prevent deformed babies; others say the government should not tell women what to do with their bodies.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Israeli Soldier to Be Charged With Manslaughter in Shooting of Palestinian Assailant
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the Israeli military court in Kiryat Malakhi last month rallied in support of a soldier who was caught on video shooting a wounded Palestinian assailant who appeared to have been subdued.
item.description: The episode, captured on video, has pitted military and defense officials who say procedures were breached against those who see the soldier as a hero.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: With Czechia, Czech Republic Hopes Vowels Will Solve Name Puzzle
item.media:description: A teacher in Prague listing in English, French and Spanish a new proposed name for the Czech Republic. Czech leaders are hoping a new name will bolster the country’s recognition on the global stage.
item.description: While the moniker does not necessarily end the potential confusion with other countries, proponents hope it rolls off the tongue in English more easily.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Pakistan’s Premier Leaves the Country Amid Panama Papers Scandal
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, right, in Islamabad last month. Mr. Sharif traveled to London on Wednesday for medical treatment.
item.description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif left Pakistan to receive medical treatment in London in the middle of an unfolding scandal over his family’s offshore wealth.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: In Brexit Debate, English Fishermen Eye Waters Free of E.U.
item.media:description: More than a third of the fleets operating off England’s southwest coast are owned by foreigners, Jim Portus said.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: As the vote on “Brexit” nears, an English Channel port is leaning toward Britain’s leaving the European Union and regaining control of its fishing grounds.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Vladimir Putin’s Vulnerable Side Is at Fore in Call-In Show
item.description: Domestic concerns, not international swaggering, dominated the choreographed call-in show, amid a second, punishing year of recession in Russia.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Belgian Court Lengthens Prison Term of Jihadist Recruiter
item.description: The sentence for Khalid Zerkani, convicted of recruiting young men to join the jihadist fight in Syria, was increased from 12 years to 15.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Memo From Germany: Angela Merkel, Accused of Betraying Core Values, Faces a Balancing Act With Turkey
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany after a news conference in Berlin on Thursday.
item.description: The political costs of doing business with the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, are becoming clearer by the week for the German chancellor.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Poll of British Muslims Reveals Startling Views, but Some Question Methodology
item.media:description: Muslim men at the Baitul Futuh Mosque in London. A new poll revealed views among Britain’s largest religious minority that differed from the greater population’s.
item.description: A new poll of British Muslims revealed attitudes on homosexuality and terrorism sharply out of step with broader public opinion.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Chacha the Chimp Escapes Japanese Zoo, Then Takes a Fall
item.description: A video shows the capture of a chimpanzee two hours after he fled from a zoo in northern Japan.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Letter From Africa: Revelations From Panama Papers Are Old News for Africans
item.media:description: Khulubuse Zuma, a nephew of President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa, is among the the African political elites cited in the Panama Papers.
item.description: Many in Africa have long known that billions of dollars are being spirited away to tax havens every year, making their lives even more precarious.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Iran’s President Is Squeezed by Opposition Leader’s Demand for a Trial
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani on Thursday. The president has promised to end house arrest for Mehdi Karroubi and two other leaders of the reformist Green Movement.
item.description: The request by the opposition leader, Mehdi Karroubi, who is under house arrest, highlighted a deepening rift in Iran’s reformist wing.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Japan’s Kyushu Island, Killing at Least 9
item.media:description: A collapsed wall in Mashiki, Kumamoto Prefecture, after a strong earthquake struck Japan on Thursday.
item.description: The quake in the country’s southwest collapsed roads and buildings, knocked out power and was followed by a series of powerful aftershocks.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: After South Korea Spurns Park Geun-hye, She May Press Agenda Abroad
item.media:description: Sorting ballots in a gymnasium in Seoul, South Korea. The Saenuri Party of President Park Geun-hye lost its majority in Parliament on Wednesday.
item.description: The president’s party lost its majority, prompting speculation that she might bolster her relevance with a bold foreign policy move. What that might be was not clear.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The End of Catholic Guilt
item.description: Pope Francis is merely acknowledging the obvious. As before, he’s using words to change hearts.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY EGAN
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Editorial Observer: In Paris, a Protest Movement Awakens
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at Place de La Republique in Paris on Tuesday.
item.description: Students are rising up against the existing political and economic order.
item.dc:creator: MIRA KAMDAR

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Death of Liberalism
item.description: Authoritarianism is ascendant and with it anti-rational bigotry. History does not end. It eddies.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Feature: The New Europeans
item.media:description: The Mzayek family outside a shelter in Eisenärzt.
item.media:credit: Hellen van Meene for The New York Times
item.description: As refugees stream into Europe, and terror attacks spark security fears, one Bavarian village grapples with newcomers — and with the question of what it means to be German.
item.dc:creator: JAMES ANGELOS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Victims of the Brussels Attacks
item.description: Thirty-five victims from at least eight countries were killed in the attacks. Here are profiles of some of the victims, updated as more names are confirmed.

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
